text_entry: To sing a song that old was sung,

text_entry: Assuming man's infirmities,

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: To glad your ear, and please your eyes.

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: It hath been sung at festivals,

speaker: LODOVICO

text_entry: The purchase is to make men glorious;

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: Et bonum quo antiquius, eo melius.

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: If you, born in these latter times,

text_entry: When wit's more ripe, accept my rhymes.

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: And that to hear an old man sing

text_entry: May to your wishes pleasure bring

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: I life would wish, and that I might

text_entry: Waste it for you, like taper-light.

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: This Antioch, then, Antiochus the Great

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: Built up, this city, for his chiefest seat:

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: The fairest in all Syria,

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: I tell you what mine authors say:

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: This king unto him took a fere,

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: Who died and left a female heir,

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: So buxom, blithe, and full of face,

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: As heaven had lent her all his grace;

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: With whom the father liking took,

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: And her to incest did provoke:

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: Bad child; worse father! to entice his own

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: To evil should be done by none:

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: But custom what they did begin

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: Was with long use account no sin.

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: The beauty of this sinful dame

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: Made many princes thither frame,

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: To seek her as a bed-fellow,

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: In marriage-pleasures play-fellow:

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: Which to prevent he made a law,

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: To keep her still, and men in awe,

speaker: LODOVICO

speaker: LODOVICO

speaker: LODOVICO

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: What now ensues, to the judgment of your eye

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: I give, my cause who best can justify.

speaker: LODOVICO

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.

speaker: LODOVICO
text_entry: Enter ANTIOCHUS, Prince PERICLES, and followers

text_entry: That have inflamed desire in my breast

text_entry: With golden fruit, but dangerous to be touch'd;

speaker: ANTIOCHUS
text_entry: Her face, like heaven, enticeth thee to view

text_entry: Her countless glory, which desert must gain;

speaker: ANTIOCHUS
text_entry: And which, without desert, because thine eye

text_entry: Presumes to reach, all thy whole heap must die.

speaker: ANTIOCHUS
text_entry: Yon sometimes famous princes, like thyself,

speaker: ANTIOCHUS

speaker: ANTIOCHUS

speaker: PERICLES

speaker: PERICLES

speaker: Daughter

speaker: PERICLES

speaker: PERICLES

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: their will;

speaker: PERICLES

text_entry: He'll stop the course by which it might be known;

speaker: PERICLES

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And with the ostent of war will look so huge,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Amazement shall drive courage from the state;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Our men be vanquish'd ere they do resist,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And subjects punish'd that ne'er thought offence:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which care of them, not pity of myself,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Who am no more but as the tops of trees,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which fence the roots they grow by and defend them,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And punish that before that he would punish.

text_entry: When Signior Sooth here does proclaim a peace,

text_entry: He flatters you, makes war upon your life.

text_entry: faults hid!

text_entry: Where as thou know'st, against the face of death,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: From whence an issue I might propagate,

speaker: PERICLES

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Her face was to mine eye beyond all wonder;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: The rest--hark in thine ear--as black as incest:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which by my knowledge found, the sinful father

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Seem'd not to strike, but smooth: but thou

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: know'st this,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: 'Tis time to fear when tyrants seem to kiss.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Such fear so grew in me, I hither fled,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Under the covering of a careful night,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Who seem'd my good protector; and, being here,

text_entry: Bethought me what was past, what might succeed.

speaker: PERICLES

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And should he doubt it, as no doubt he doth,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: That I should open to the listening air

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: How many worthy princes' bloods were shed,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: To keep his bed of blackness unlaid ope,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: To lop that doubt, he'll fill this land with arms,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And make pretence of wrong that I have done him:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: When all, for mine, if I may call offence,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Must feel war's blow, who spares not innocence:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which love to all, of which thyself art one,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Who now reprovest me for it,--

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Alas, sir!

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Drew sleep out of mine eyes, blood from my cheeks,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Musings into my mind, with thousand doubts

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: How I might stop this tempest ere it came;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And finding little comfort to relieve them,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I thought it princely charity to grieve them.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Well, my lord, since you have given me leave to speak.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Freely will I speak. Antiochus you fear,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: And justly too, I think, you fear the tyrant,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Who either by public war or private treason

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Will take away your life.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Therefore, my lord, go travel for a while,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Till that his rage and anger be forgot,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Or till the Destinies do cut his thread of life.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Your rule direct to any; if to me.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Day serves not light more faithful than I'll be.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I do not doubt thy faith;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: But should he wrong my liberties in my absence?

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: We'll mingle our bloods together in the earth,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: From whence we had our being and our birth.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Tyre, I now look from thee then, and to Tarsus

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Intend my travel, where I'll hear from thee;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And by whose letters I'll dispose myself.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: The care I had and have of subjects' good

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: On thee I lay whose wisdom's strength can bear it.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I'll take thy word for faith, not ask thine oath:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Who shuns not to break one will sure crack both:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: But in our orbs we'll live so round and safe,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: That time of both this truth shall ne'er convince,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Thou show'dst a subject's shine, I a true prince.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Enter THALIARD

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: So, this is Tyre, and this the court. Here must I

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: kill King Pericles; and if I do it not, I am sure to

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: be hanged at home: 'tis dangerous. Well, I perceive

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: he was a wise fellow, and had good discretion, that,

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: being bid to ask what he would of the king, desired

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: he might know none of his secrets: now do I see he

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: had some reason for't; for if a king bid a man be a

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: villain, he's bound by the indenture of his oath to

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: be one! Hush! here come the lords of Tyre.

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: You shall not need, my fellow peers of Tyre,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Further to question me of your king's departure:

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: His seal'd commission, left in trust with me,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Doth speak sufficiently he's gone to travel.

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: [Aside]  How! the king gone!

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: If further yet you will be satisfied,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Why, as it were unlicensed of your loves,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: He would depart, I'll give some light unto you.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Being at Antioch--

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: [Aside]          What from Antioch?

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Royal Antiochus--on what cause I know not--

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Took some displeasure at him; at least he judged so:

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: And doubting lest that he had err'd or sinn'd,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: To show his sorrow, he'ld correct himself;

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: So puts himself unto the shipman's toil,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: With whom each minute threatens life or death.

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: [Aside]  Well, I perceive

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: I shall not be hang'd now, although I would;

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: But since he's gone, the king's seas must please:

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: He 'scaped the land, to perish at the sea.

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: I'll present myself. Peace to the lords of Tyre!

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Lord Thaliard from Antiochus is welcome.

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: From him I come

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: With message unto princely Pericles;

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: But since my landing I have understood

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: Your lord has betook himself to unknown travels,

speaker: THALIARD
text_entry: My message must return from whence it came.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: We have no reason to desire it,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Commended to our master, not to us:

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Yet, ere you shall depart, this we desire,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: As friends to Antioch, we may feast in Tyre.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA, and others

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: My Dionyza, shall we rest us here,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: And by relating tales of others' griefs,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: See if 'twill teach us to forget our own?

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: That were to blow at fire in hope to quench it;

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: For who digs hills because they do aspire

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Throws down one mountain to cast up a higher.

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: O my distressed lord, even such our griefs are;

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Here they're but felt, and seen with mischief's eyes,

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: But like to groves, being topp'd, they higher rise.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: O Dionyza,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Who wanteth food, and will not say he wants it,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Or can conceal his hunger till he famish?

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Our tongues and sorrows do sound deep

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Our woes into the air; our eyes do weep,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Till tongues fetch breath that may proclaim them louder;

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: That, if heaven slumber while their creatures want,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: They may awake their helps to comfort them.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: I'll then discourse our woes, felt several years,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: And wanting breath to speak help me with tears.

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: I'll do my best, sir.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: This Tarsus, o'er which I have the government,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: A city on whom plenty held full hand,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: For riches strew'd herself even in the streets;

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Whose towers bore heads so high they kiss'd the clouds,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: And strangers ne'er beheld but wondered at;

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Whose men and dames so jetted and adorn'd,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Like one another's glass to trim them by:

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Their tables were stored full, to glad the sight,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: And not so much to feed on as delight;

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: All poverty was scorn'd, and pride so great,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: The name of help grew odious to repeat.

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: O, 'tis too true.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: But see what heaven can do! By this our change,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: These mouths, who but of late, earth, sea, and air,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Were all too little to content and please,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Although they gave their creatures in abundance,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: As houses are defiled for want of use,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: They are now starved for want of exercise:

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Those palates who, not yet two summers younger,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Must have inventions to delight the taste,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Would now be glad of bread, and beg for it:

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Those mothers who, to nousle up their babes,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Thought nought too curious, are ready now

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: To eat those little darlings whom they loved.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: So sharp are hunger's teeth, that man and wife

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Draw lots who first shall die to lengthen life:

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Here stands a lord, and there a lady weeping;

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Here many sink, yet those which see them fall

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Have scarce strength left to give them burial.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Is not this true?

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Our cheeks and hollow eyes do witness it.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: O, let those cities that of plenty's cup

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: And her prosperities so largely taste,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: With their superfluous riots, hear these tears!

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: The misery of Tarsus may be theirs.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Enter a Lord

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Where's the lord governor?

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Here.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Speak out thy sorrows which thou bring'st in haste,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: For comfort is too far for us to expect.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: We have descried, upon our neighbouring shore,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: A portly sail of ships make hitherward.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: I thought as much.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: One sorrow never comes but brings an heir,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: That may succeed as his inheritor;

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: And so in ours: some neighbouring nation,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Taking advantage of our misery,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Hath stuff'd these hollow vessels with their power,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: To beat us down, the which are down already;

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: And make a conquest of unhappy me,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Whereas no glory's got to overcome.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: That's the least fear; for, by the semblance

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Of their white flags display'd, they bring us peace,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And come to us as favourers, not as foes.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Thou speak'st like him's untutor'd to repeat:

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Who makes the fairest show means most deceit.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: But bring they what they will and what they can,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: What need we fear?

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: The ground's the lowest, and we are half way there.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Go tell their general we attend him here,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: To know for what he comes, and whence he comes,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: And what he craves.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: I go, my lord.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Welcome is peace, if he on peace consist;

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: If wars, we are unable to resist.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Enter PERICLES with Attendants

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Lord governor, for so we hear you are,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Let not our ships and number of our men

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Be like a beacon fired to amaze your eyes.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: We have heard your miseries as far as Tyre,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And seen the desolation of your streets:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Nor come we to add sorrow to your tears,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: But to relieve them of their heavy load;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And these our ships, you happily may think

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Are like the Trojan horse was stuff'd within

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: With bloody veins, expecting overthrow,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Are stored with corn to make your needy bread,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And give them life whom hunger starved half dead.

speaker: All
text_entry: The gods of Greece protect you!

speaker: All
text_entry: And we'll pray for you.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Arise, I pray you, rise:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: We do not look for reverence, but to love,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And harbourage for ourself, our ships, and men.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: The which when any shall not gratify,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Or pay you with unthankfulness in thought,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Be it our wives, our children, or ourselves,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: The curse of heaven and men succeed their evils!

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Till when,--the which I hope shall ne'er be seen,--

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Your grace is welcome to our town and us.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which welcome we'll accept; feast here awhile,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Until our stars that frown lend us a smile.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Enter GOWER

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Here have you seen a mighty king

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: His child, I wis, to incest bring;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: A better prince and benign lord,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: That will prove awful both in deed and word.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Be quiet then as men should be,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Till he hath pass'd necessity.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: I'll show you those in troubles reign,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Losing a mite, a mountain gain.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: The good in conversation,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: To whom I give my benison,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Is still at Tarsus, where each man

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Thinks all is writ he speken can;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: And, to remember what he does,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Build his statue to make him glorious:

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: But tidings to the contrary

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Are brought your eyes; what need speak I?

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: DUMB SHOW.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Enter at one door PERICLES talking with CLEON; all  the train with them. Enter at another door a  Gentleman, with a letter to PERICLES; PERICLES  shows the letter to CLEON; gives the Messenger a  reward, and knights him. Exit PERICLES at one door, and CLEON at another

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Good Helicane, that stay'd at home,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Not to eat honey like a drone

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: From others' labours; for though he strive

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: To killen bad, keep good alive;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: And to fulfil his prince' desire,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Sends word of all that haps in Tyre:

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: How Thaliard came full bent with sin

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: And had intent to murder him;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: And that in Tarsus was not best

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Longer for him to make his rest.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: He, doing so, put forth to seas,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Where when men been, there's seldom ease;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: For now the wind begins to blow;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Thunder above and deeps below

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Make such unquiet, that the ship

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Should house him safe is wreck'd and split;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: And he, good prince, having all lost,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: By waves from coast to coast is tost:

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: All perishen of man, of pelf,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Ne aught escapen but himself;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Till fortune, tired with doing bad,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Threw him ashore, to give him glad:

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: And here he comes. What shall be next,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Pardon old Gower,--this longs the text.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Enter PERICLES, wet

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Yet cease your ire, you angry stars of heaven!

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Wind, rain, and thunder, remember, earthly man

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Is but a substance that must yield to you;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And I, as fits my nature, do obey you:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Alas, the sea hath cast me on the rocks,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Wash'd me from shore to shore, and left me breath

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Nothing to think on but ensuing death:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Let it suffice the greatness of your powers

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: To have bereft a prince of all his fortunes;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And having thrown him from your watery grave,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Here to have death in peace is all he'll crave.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Enter three FISHERMEN

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: What, ho, Pilch!

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: Ha, come and bring away the nets!

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: What, Patch-breech, I say!

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: What say you, master?

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Look how thou stirrest now! come away, or I'll

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: fetch thee with a wanion.

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: Faith, master, I am thinking of the poor men that

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: were cast away before us even now.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Alas, poor souls, it grieved my heart to hear what

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: pitiful cries they made to us to help them, when,

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: well-a-day, we could scarce help ourselves.

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: Nay, master, said not I as much when I saw the

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: porpus how he bounced and tumbled? they say

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: they're half fish, half flesh: a plague on them,

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: they ne'er come but I look to be washed. Master, I

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: marvel how the fishes live in the sea.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Why, as men do a-land; the great ones eat up the

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: little ones: I can compare our rich misers to

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: nothing so fitly as to a whale; a' plays and

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: tumbles, driving the poor fry before him, and at

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: last devours them all at a mouthful: such whales

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: have I heard on o' the land, who never leave gaping

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: till they've swallowed the whole parish, church,

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: steeple, bells, and all.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: [Aside]  A pretty moral.

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: But, master, if I had been the sexton, I would have

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: been that day in the belfry.

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: Why, man?

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: Because he should have swallowed me too: and when I

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: had been in his belly, I would have kept such a

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: jangling of the bells, that he should never have

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: left, till he cast bells, steeple, church, and

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: parish up again. But if the good King Simonides

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: were of my mind,--

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: [Aside]  Simonides!

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: We would purge the land of these drones, that rob

speaker: Third Fisherman
text_entry: the bee of her honey.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: [Aside]  How from the finny subject of the sea

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: These fishers tell the infirmities of men;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And from their watery empire recollect

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: All that may men approve or men detect!

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Peace be at your labour, honest fishermen.

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: Honest! good fellow, what's that? If it be a day

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: fits you, search out of the calendar, and nobody

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: look after it.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: May see the sea hath cast upon your coast.

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: What a drunken knave was the sea to cast thee in our

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: way!

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: A man whom both the waters and the wind,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: In that vast tennis-court, have made the ball

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: For them to play upon, entreats you pity him:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: He asks of you, that never used to beg.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: No, friend, cannot you beg? Here's them in our

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: country Greece gets more with begging than we can do

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: with working.

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: Canst thou catch any fishes, then?

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I never practised it.

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: Nay, then thou wilt starve, sure; for here's nothing

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: to be got now-a-days, unless thou canst fish for't.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: What I have been I have forgot to know;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: But what I am, want teaches me to think on:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: A man throng'd up with cold: my veins are chill,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And have no more of life than may suffice

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: To give my tongue that heat to ask your help;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which if you shall refuse, when I am dead,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: For that I am a man, pray see me buried.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Die quoth-a? Now gods forbid! I have a gown here;

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: come, put it on; keep thee warm. Now, afore me, a

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: handsome fellow! Come, thou shalt go home, and

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: we'll have flesh for holidays, fish for

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: fasting-days, and moreo'er puddings and flap-jacks,

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: and thou shalt be welcome.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I thank you, sir.

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: Hark you, my friend; you said you could not beg.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I did but crave.

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: But crave! Then I'll turn craver too, and so I

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: shall 'scape whipping.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Why, are all your beggars whipped, then?

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: O, not all, my friend, not all; for if all your

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: beggars were whipped, I would wish no better office

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: than to be beadle. But, master, I'll go draw up the

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: net.

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: Exit with Third Fisherman

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: [Aside]  How well this honest mirth becomes their labour!

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Hark you, sir, do you know where ye are?

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Not well.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Why, I'll tell you: this is called Pentapolis, and

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: our king the good Simonides.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: The good King Simonides, do you call him.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Ay, sir; and he deserves so to be called for his

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: peaceable reign and good government.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: He is a happy king, since he gains from his subjects

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: the name of good by his government. How far is his

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: court distant from this shore?

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Marry, sir, half a day's journey: and I'll tell

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: you, he hath a fair daughter, and to-morrow is her

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: birth-day; and there are princes and knights come

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: from all parts of the world to just and tourney for her love.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Were my fortunes equal to my desires, I could wish

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: to make one there.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: O, sir, things must be as they may; and what a man

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: cannot get, he may lawfully deal for--his wife's soul.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: Help, master, help! here's a fish hangs in the net,

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: like a poor man's right in the law; 'twill hardly

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: come out. Ha! bots on't, 'tis come at last, and

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: 'tis turned to a rusty armour.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: An armour, friends! I pray you, let me see it.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Thanks, fortune, yet, that, after all my crosses,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Thou givest me somewhat to repair myself;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And though it was mine own, part of my heritage,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which my dead father did bequeath to me.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: With this strict charge, even as he left his life,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: 'Keep it, my Pericles; it hath been a shield

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Twixt me and death;'--and pointed to this brace;--

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: 'For that it saved me, keep it; in like necessity--

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: The which the gods protect thee from!--may

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: defend thee.'

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: It kept where I kept, I so dearly loved it;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Till the rough seas, that spare not any man,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Took it in rage, though calm'd have given't again:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I thank thee for't: my shipwreck now's no ill,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Since I have here my father's gift in's will.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: What mean you, sir?

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: To beg of you, kind friends, this coat of worth,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: For it was sometime target to a king;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I know it by this mark. He loved me dearly,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And for his sake I wish the having of it;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And that you'ld guide me to your sovereign's court,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Where with it I may appear a gentleman;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And if that ever my low fortune's better,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I'll pay your bounties; till then rest your debtor.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Why, wilt thou tourney for the lady?

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I'll show the virtue I have borne in arms.

speaker: First Fisherman
text_entry: Why, do 'e take it, and the gods give thee good on't!

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: Ay, but hark you, my friend; 'twas we that made up

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: this garment through the rough seams of the waters:

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: there are certain condolements, certain vails. I

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: hope, sir, if you thrive, you'll remember from

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: whence you had it.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Believe 't, I will.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: By your furtherance I am clothed in steel;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And, spite of all the rapture of the sea,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: This jewel holds his building on my arm:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Unto thy value I will mount myself

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Upon a courser, whose delightful steps

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Shall make the gazer joy to see him tread.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Only, my friend, I yet am unprovided

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Of a pair of bases.

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: We'll sure provide: thou shalt have my best gown to

speaker: Second Fisherman
text_entry: make thee a pair; and I'll bring thee to the court myself.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Then honour be but a goal to my will,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: This day I'll rise, or else add ill to ill.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: reception of King, Princess, Lords,  and c.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, and Attendants

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Are the knights ready to begin the triumph?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: They are, my liege;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And stay your coming to present themselves.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Return them, we are ready; and our daughter,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: In honour of whose birth these triumphs are,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Sits here, like beauty's child, whom nature gat

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: For men to see, and seeing wonder at.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Exit a Lord

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: It pleaseth you, my royal father, to express

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: My commendations great, whose merit's less.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: It's fit it should be so; for princes are

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: A model which heaven makes like to itself:

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: As jewels lose their glory if neglected,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: So princes their renowns if not respected.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: 'Tis now your honour, daughter, to explain

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: The labour of each knight in his device.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Which, to preserve mine honour, I'll perform.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Enter a Knight; he passes over, and his Squire presents his shield to the Princess

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Who is the first that doth prefer himself?

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: A knight of Sparta, my renowned father;

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: And the device he bears upon his shield

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Is a black Ethiope reaching at the sun

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The word, 'Lux tua vita mihi.'

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: He loves you well that holds his life of you.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: The Second Knight passes over

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Who is the second that presents himself?

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: A prince of Macedon, my royal father;

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: And the device he bears upon his shield

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Is an arm'd knight that's conquer'd by a lady;

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The motto thus, in Spanish, 'Piu por dulzura que por fuerza.'

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The Third Knight passes over

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And what's the third?

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The third of Antioch;

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: And his device, a wreath of chivalry;

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The word, 'Me pompae provexit apex.'

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The Fourth Knight passes over

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: What is the fourth?

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: A burning torch that's turned upside down;

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The word, 'Quod me alit, me extinguit.'

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Which shows that beauty hath his power and will,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Which can as well inflame as it can kill.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: The Fifth Knight passes over

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The fifth, an hand environed with clouds,

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Holding out gold that's by the touchstone tried;

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The motto thus, 'Sic spectanda fides.'

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The Sixth Knight, PERICLES, passes over

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And what's

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: The sixth and last, the which the knight himself

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: With such a graceful courtesy deliver'd?

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: He seems to be a stranger; but his present is

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: A wither'd branch, that's only green at top;

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The motto, 'In hac spe vivo.'

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: A pretty moral;

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: From the dejected state wherein he is,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: He hopes by you his fortunes yet may flourish.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: He had need mean better than his outward show

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Can any way speak in his just commend;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: For by his rusty outside he appears

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: To have practised more the whipstock than the lance.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: He well may be a stranger, for he comes

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: To an honour'd triumph strangely furnished.

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: And on set purpose let his armour rust

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: Until this day, to scour it in the dust.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Opinion's but a fool, that makes us scan

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: The outward habit by the inward man.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: But stay, the knights are coming: we will withdraw

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Into the gallery.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Great shouts within and all cry 'The mean knight!'

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Knights,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: To say you're welcome were superfluous.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: To place upon the volume of your deeds,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: As in a title-page, your worth in arms,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Were more than you expect, or more than's fit,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Since every worth in show commends itself.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Prepare for mirth, for mirth becomes a feast:

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: You are princes and my guests.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: But you, my knight and guest;

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: To whom this wreath of victory I give,

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: And crown you king of this day's happiness.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: 'Tis more by fortune, lady, than by merit.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Call it by what you will, the day is yours;

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And here, I hope, is none that envies it.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: In framing an artist, art hath thus decreed,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: To make some good, but others to exceed;

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And you are her labour'd scholar. Come, queen o'

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: the feast,--

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: For, daughter, so you are,--here take your place:

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Marshal the rest, as they deserve their grace.

speaker: KNIGHTS
text_entry: We are honour'd much by good Simonides.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Your presence glads our days: honour we love;

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: For who hates honour hates the gods above.

speaker: Marshal
text_entry: Sir, yonder is your place.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Some other is more fit.

speaker: First Knight
text_entry: Contend not, sir; for we are gentlemen

speaker: First Knight
text_entry: That neither in our hearts nor outward eyes

speaker: First Knight
text_entry: Envy the great nor do the low despise.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: You are right courteous knights.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Sit, sir, sit.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: By Jove, I wonder, that is king of thoughts,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: These cates resist me, she but thought upon.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: By Juno, that is queen of marriage,

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: All viands that I eat do seem unsavoury.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Wishing him my meat. Sure, he's a gallant gentleman.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: He's but a country gentleman;

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Has done no more than other knights have done;

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Has broken a staff or so; so let it pass.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: To me he seems like diamond to glass.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Yon king's to me like to my father's picture,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Which tells me in that glory once he was;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Had princes sit, like stars, about his throne,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And he the sun, for them to reverence;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: None that beheld him, but, like lesser lights,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Did vail their crowns to his supremacy:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Where now his son's like a glow-worm in the night,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: The which hath fire in darkness, none in light:

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Whereby I see that Time's the king of men,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: He's both their parent, and he is their grave,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And gives them what he will, not what they crave.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: What, are you merry, knights?

speaker: Knights
text_entry: Who can be other in this royal presence?

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Here, with a cup that's stored unto the brim,--

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: As you do love, fill to your mistress' lips,--

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: We drink this health to you.

speaker: KNIGHTS
text_entry: We thank your grace.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Yet pause awhile:

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Yon knight doth sit too melancholy,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: As if the entertainment in our court

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Had not a show might countervail his worth.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Note it not you, Thaisa?

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: What is it

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: To me, my father?

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: O, attend, my daughter:

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Princes in this should live like gods above,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Who freely give to every one that comes

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: To honour them:

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And princes not doin g so are like to gnats,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Which make a sound, but kill'd are wonder'd at.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Therefore to make his entrance more sweet,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Here, say we drink this standing-bowl of wine to him.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Alas, my father, it befits not me

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Unto a stranger knight to be so bold:

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: He may my proffer take for an offence,

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Since men take women's gifts for impudence.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: How!

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Do as I bid you, or you'll move me else.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: [Aside]  Now, by the gods, he could not please me better.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And furthermore tell him, we desire to know of him,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Of whence he is, his name and parentage.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: The king my father, sir, has drunk to you.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I thank him.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Wishing it so much blood unto your life.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I thank both him and you, and pledge him freely.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: And further he desires to know of you,

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Of whence you are, your name and parentage.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: A gentleman of Tyre; my name, Pericles;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: My education been in arts and arms;

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Who, looking for adventures in the world,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: Was by the rough seas reft of ships and men,

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: And after shipwreck driven upon this shore.

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: He thanks your grace; names himself Pericles,

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: A gentleman of Tyre,

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Who only by misfortune of the seas

speaker: THAISA
text_entry: Bereft of ships and men, cast on this shore.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Now, by the gods, I pity his misfortune,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And will awake him from his melancholy.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Come, gentlemen, we sit too long on trifles,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And waste the time, which looks for other revels.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Even in your armours, as you are address'd,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Will very well become a soldier's dance.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: I will not have excuse, with saying this

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Loud music is too harsh for ladies' heads,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Since they love men in arms as well as beds.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: The Knights dance

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: So, this was well ask'd,'twas so well perform'd.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Come, sir;

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Here is a lady that wants breathing too:

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And I have heard, you knights of Tyre

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Are excellent in making ladies trip;

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And that their measures are as excellent.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: In those that practise them they are, my lord.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: O, that's as much as you would be denied

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Of your fair courtesy.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: The Knights and Ladies dance

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Unclasp, unclasp:

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Thanks, gentlemen, to all; all have done well.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: To PERICLES

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: But you the best. Pages and lights, to conduct

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: These knights unto their several lodgings!

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: To PERICLES

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Yours, sir,

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: We have given order to be next our own.

speaker: PERICLES
text_entry: I am at your grace's pleasure.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Princes, it is too late to talk of love;

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: And that's the mark I know you level at:

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Therefore each one betake him to his rest;

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: To-morrow all for speeding do their best.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.

speaker: SIMONIDES
text_entry: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: No, Escanes, know this of me,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Antiochus from incest lived not free:

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: For which, the most high gods not minding longer

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: To withhold the vengeance that they had in store,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Due to this heinous capital offence,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Even in the height and pride of all his glory,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: When he was seated in a chariot

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Of an inestimable value, and his daughter with him,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: A fire from heaven came and shrivell'd up

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Their bodies, even to loathing; for they so stunk,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: That all those eyes adored them ere their fall

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Scorn now their hand should give them burial.

speaker: ESCANES
text_entry: 'Twas very strange.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: And yet but justice; for though

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: This king were great, his greatness was no guard

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: To bar heaven's shaft, but sin had his reward.

speaker: ESCANES
text_entry: 'Tis very true.

speaker: ESCANES
text_entry: Enter two or three Lords

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: See, not a man in private conference

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Or council has respect with him but he.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: It shall no longer grieve without reproof.

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: And cursed be he that will not second it.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Follow me, then. Lord Helicane, a word.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: With me? and welcome: happy day, my lords.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Know that our griefs are risen to the top,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And now at length they overflow their banks.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Your griefs! for what? wrong not your prince you love.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Wrong not yourself, then, noble Helicane;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: But if the prince do live, let us salute him,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Or know what ground's made happy by his breath.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: If in the world he live, we'll seek him out;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: If in his grave he rest, we'll find him there;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And be resolved he lives to govern us,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Or dead, give's cause to mourn his funeral,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And leave us to our free election.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Whose death indeed's the strongest in our censure:

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: And knowing this kingdom is without a head,--

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Like goodly buildings left without a roof

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Soon fall to ruin,--your noble self,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: That best know how to rule and how to reign,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: We thus submit unto,--our sovereign.

speaker: All
text_entry: Live, noble Helicane!

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: For honour's cause, forbear your suffrages:

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: If that you love Prince Pericles, forbear.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Take I your wish, I leap into the seas,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Where's hourly trouble for a minute's ease.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: A twelvemonth longer, let me entreat you to

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Forbear the absence of your king:

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: If in which time expired, he not return,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: I shall with aged patience bear your yoke.

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: But if I cannot win you to this love,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Go search like nobles, like noble subjects,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: And in your search spend your adventurous worth;

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: Whom if you find, and win unto return,

speaker: HELICANUS
text_entry: You shall like diamonds sit about his crown.

speaker: First Lord

text_entry: Come, other sorts offend as well as we.

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: As well as we! ay, and better too; we offend worse.

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: Neither is our profession any trade; it's no

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: calling. But here comes Boult.

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: Re-enter BOULT, with the Pirates and MARINA

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: [To MARINA]  Come your ways. My masters, you say

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: she's a virgin?

speaker: First Pirate
text_entry: O, sir, we doubt it not.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: Master, I have gone through for this piece, you see:

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: if you like her, so; if not, I have lost my earnest.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Boult, has she any qualities?

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: She has a good face, speaks well, and has excellent

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: good clothes: there's no further necessity of

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: qualities can make her be refused.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: What's her price, Boult?

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: I cannot be bated one doit of a thousand pieces.

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: Well, follow me, my masters, you shall have your

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: money presently. Wife, take her in; instruct her

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: what she has to do, that she may not be raw in her

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: entertainment.

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: Exeunt Pandar and Pirates

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Boult, take you the marks of her, the colour of her

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: hair, complexion, height, age, with warrant of her

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: virginity; and cry 'He that will give most shall

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: have her first.' Such a maidenhead were no cheap

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: thing, if men were as they have been. Get this done

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: as I command you.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: Performance shall follow.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: Alack that Leonine was so slack, so slow!

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: He should have struck, not spoke; or that these pirates,

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: Not enough barbarous, had not o'erboard thrown me

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: For to seek my mother!

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Why lament you, pretty one?

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: That I am pretty.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Come, the gods have done their part in you.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: I accuse them not.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: You are light into my hands, where you are like to live.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: The more my fault

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: To scape his hands where I was like to die.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Ay, and you shall live in pleasure.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: No.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Yes, indeed shall you, and taste gentlemen of all

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: fashions: you shall fare well; you shall have the

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: difference of all complexions. What! do you stop your ears?

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: Are you a woman?

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: What would you have me be, an I be not a woman?

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: An honest woman, or not a woman.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Marry, whip thee, gosling: I think I shall have

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: something to do with you. Come, you're a young

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: foolish sapling, and must be bowed as I would have

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: you.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: The gods defend me!

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: If it please the gods to defend you by men, then men

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: must comfort you, men must feed you, men must stir

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: you up. Boult's returned.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Re-enter BOULT

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Now, sir, hast thou cried her through the market?

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: I have cried her almost to the number of her hairs;

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: I have drawn her picture with my voice.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: And I prithee tell me, how dost thou find the

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: inclination of the people, especially of the younger sort?

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: 'Faith, they listened to me as they would have

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: hearkened to their father's testament. There was a

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: Spaniard's mouth so watered, that he went to bed to

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: her very description.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: We shall have him here to-morrow with his best ruff on.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: To-night, to-night. But, mistress, do you know the

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: French knight that cowers i' the hams?

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Who, Monsieur Veroles?

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: Ay, he: he offered to cut a caper at the

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: proclamation; but he made a groan at it, and swore

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: he would see her to-morrow.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Well, well; as for him, he brought his disease

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: hither: here he does but repair it. I know he will

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: come in our shadow, to scatter his crowns in the

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: sun.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: Well, if we had of every nation a traveller, we

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: should lodge them with this sign.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: [To MARINA]  Pray you, come hither awhile. You

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: have fortunes coming upon you. Mark me: you must

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: seem to do that fearfully which you commit

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: willingly, despise profit where you have most gain.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: To weep that you live as ye do makes pity in your

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: lovers: seldom but that pity begets you a good

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: opinion, and that opinion a mere profit.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: I understand you not.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: O, take her home, mistress, take her home: these

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: blushes of hers must be quenched with some present practise.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Thou sayest true, i' faith, so they must; for your

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: bride goes to that with shame which is her way to go

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: with warrant.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: 'Faith, some do, and some do not. But, mistress, if

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: I have bargained for the joint,--

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Thou mayst cut a morsel off the spit.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: I may so.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Who should deny it? Come, young one, I like the

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: manner of your garments well.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: Ay, by my faith, they shall not be changed yet.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Boult, spend thou that in the town: report what a

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: sojourner we have; you'll lose nothing by custom.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: When nature flamed this piece, she meant thee a good

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: turn; therefore say what a paragon she is, and thou

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: hast the harvest out of thine own report.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: I warrant you, mistress, thunder shall not so awake

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: the beds of eels as my giving out her beauty stir up

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: the lewdly-inclined. I'll bring home some to-night.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Come your ways; follow me.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: If fires be hot, knives sharp, or waters deep,

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: Untied I still my virgin knot will keep.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: Diana, aid my purpose!

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: What have we to do with Diana? Pray you, will you go with us?

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Enter CLEON and DIONYZA

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Why, are you foolish? Can it be undone?

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: O Dionyza, such a piece of slaughter

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: The sun and moon ne'er look'd upon!

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: I think

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: You'll turn a child again.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Were I chief lord of all this spacious world,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: I'ld give it to undo the deed. O lady,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Much less in blood than virtue, yet a princess

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: To equal any single crown o' the earth

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: I' the justice of compare! O villain Leonine!

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Whom thou hast poison'd too:

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: If thou hadst drunk to him, 't had been a kindness

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Becoming well thy fact: what canst thou say

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: When noble Pericles shall demand his child?

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: That she is dead. Nurses are not the fates,

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: To foster it, nor ever to preserve.

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: She died at night; I'll say so. Who can cross it?

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Unless you play the pious innocent,

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: And for an honest attribute cry out

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: 'She died by foul play.'

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: O, go to. Well, well,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Of all the faults beneath the heavens, the gods

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Do like this worst.

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Be one of those that think

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: The petty wrens of Tarsus will fly hence,

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: And open this to Pericles. I do shame

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: To think of what a noble strain you are,

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: And of how coward a spirit.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: To such proceeding

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Who ever but his approbation added,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Though not his prime consent, he did not flow

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: From honourable sources.

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Be it so, then:

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Yet none does know, but you, how she came dead,

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Nor none can know, Leonine being gone.

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: She did disdain my child, and stood between

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Her and her fortunes: none would look on her,

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: But cast their gazes on Marina's face;

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Whilst ours was blurted at and held a malkin

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Not worth the time of day. It pierced me through;

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: And though you call my course unnatural,

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: You not your child well loving, yet I find

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: It greets me as an enterprise of kindness

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Perform'd to your sole daughter.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Heavens forgive it!

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: And as for Pericles,

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: What should he say? We wept after her hearse,

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: And yet we mourn: her monument

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Is almost finish'd, and her epitaphs

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: In glittering golden characters express

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: A general praise to her, and care in us

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: At whose expense 'tis done.

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Thou art like the harpy,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Which, to betray, dost, with thine angel's face,

speaker: CLEON
text_entry: Seize with thine eagle's talons.

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: You are like one that superstitiously

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Doth swear to the gods that winter kills the flies:

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: But yet I know you'll do as I advise.

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: SCENE IV:

speaker: DIONYZA
text_entry: Enter GOWER, before the monument of MARINA at Tarsus

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Thus time we waste, and longest leagues make short;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Sail seas in cockles, have an wish but for't;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Making, to take your imagination,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: From bourn to bourn, region to region.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: By you being pardon'd, we commit no crime

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: To use one language in each several clime

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Where our scenes seem to live. I do beseech you

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: To learn of me, who stand i' the gaps to teach you,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: The stages of our story. Pericles

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Is now again thwarting the wayward seas,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Attended on by many a lord and knight.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: To see his daughter, all his life's delight.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Old Escanes, whom Helicanus late

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Advanced in time to great and high estate,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Is left to govern. Bear you it in mind,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Old Helicanus goes along behind.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Well-sailing ships and bounteous winds have brought

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: This king to Tarsus,--think his pilot thought;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: So with his steerage shall your thoughts grow on,--

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: To fetch his daughter home, who first is gone.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Like motes and shadows see them move awhile;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Your ears unto your eyes I'll reconcile.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: DUMB SHOW.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Enter PERICLES, at one door, with all his train;  CLEON and DIONYZA, at the other. CLEON shows  PERICLES the tomb; whereat PERICLES makes  lamentation, puts on sackcloth, and in a mighty passion departs. Then exeunt CLEON and DIONYZA

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: See how belief may suffer by foul show!

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: This borrow'd passion stands for true old woe;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: And Pericles, in sorrow all devour'd,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: With sighs shot through, and biggest tears

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: o'ershower'd,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Leaves Tarsus and again embarks. He swears

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Never to wash his face, nor cut his hairs:

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: He puts on sackcloth, and to sea. He bears

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: A tempest, which his mortal vessel tears,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: And yet he rides it out. Now please you wit.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: The epitaph is for Marina writ

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: By wicked Dionyza.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Reads the inscription on MARINA's monument

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: 'The fairest, sweet'st, and best lies here,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Who wither'd in her spring of year.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: She was of Tyrus the king's daughter,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: On whom foul death hath made this slaughter;

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Marina was she call'd; and at her birth,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Thetis, being proud, swallow'd some part o' the earth:

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Therefore the earth, fearing to be o'erflow'd,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Hath Thetis' birth-child on the heavens bestow'd:

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Wherefore she does, and swears she'll never stint,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Make raging battery upon shores of flint.'

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: No visor does become black villany

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: So well as soft and tender flattery.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Let Pericles believe his daughter's dead,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: And bear his courses to be ordered

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: By Lady Fortune; while our scene must play

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: His daughter's woe and heavy well-a-day

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: In her unholy service. Patience, then,

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: And think you now are all in Mytilene.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: SCENE V. Mytilene. A street before the brothel.

speaker: GOWER
text_entry: Enter, from the brothel, two Gentlemen

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Did you ever hear the like?

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: No, nor never shall do in such a place as this, she

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: being once gone.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: But to have divinity preached there! did you ever

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: dream of such a thing?

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: No, no. Come, I am for no more bawdy-houses:

speaker: Second Gentleman
text_entry: shall's go hear the vestals sing?

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: I'll do any thing now that is virtuous; but I

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: am out of the road of rutting for ever.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.

speaker: First Gentleman
text_entry: Enter Pandar, Bawd, and BOULT

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: Well, I had rather than twice the worth of her she

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: had ne'er come here.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Fie, fie upon her! she's able to freeze the god

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Priapus, and undo a whole generation. We must

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: either get her ravished, or be rid of her. When she

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: should do for clients her fitment, and do me the

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: kindness of our profession, she has me her quirks,

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: her reasons, her master reasons, her prayers, her

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: knees; that she would make a puritan of the devil,

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: if he should cheapen a kiss of her.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: 'Faith, I must ravish her, or she'll disfurnish us

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: of all our cavaliers, and make our swearers priests.

speaker: Pandar
text_entry: Now, the pox upon her green-sickness for me!

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: 'Faith, there's no way to be rid on't but by the

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: way to the pox. Here comes the Lord Lysimachus disguised.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: We should have both lord and lown, if the peevish

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: baggage would but give way to customers.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: Enter LYSIMACHUS

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: How now! How a dozen of virginities?

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Now, the gods to-bless your honour!

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: I am glad to see your honour in good health.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: You may so; 'tis the better for you that your

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: resorters stand upon sound legs. How now!

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: wholesome iniquity have you that a man may deal

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: withal, and defy the surgeon?

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: We have here one, sir, if she would--but there never

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: came her like in Mytilene.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: If she'ld do the deed of darkness, thou wouldst say.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Your honour knows what 'tis to say well enough.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: Well, call forth, call forth.

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: For flesh and blood, sir, white and red, you shall

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: see a rose; and she were a rose indeed, if she had but--

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: What, prithee?

speaker: BOULT
text_entry: O, sir, I can be modest.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: That dignifies the renown of a bawd, no less than it

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: gives a good report to a number to be chaste.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: Exit BOULT

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Here comes that which grows to the stalk; never

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: plucked yet, I can assure you.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Re-enter BOULT with MARINA

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Is she not a fair creature?

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: 'Faith, she would serve after a long voyage at sea.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: Well, there's for you: leave us.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: I beseech your honour, give me leave: a word, and

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: I'll have done presently.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: I beseech you, do.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: [To MARINA]  First, I would have you note, this is

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: an honourable man.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: I desire to find him so, that I may worthily note him.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Next, he's the governor of this country, and a man

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: whom I am bound to.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: If he govern the country, you are bound to him

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: indeed; but how honourable he is in that, I know not.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Pray you, without any more virginal fencing, will

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: you use him kindly? He will line your apron with gold.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: What he will do graciously, I will thankfully receive.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: Ha' you done?

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: My lord, she's not paced yet: you must take some

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: pains to work her to your manage. Come, we will

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: leave his honour and her together. Go thy ways.

speaker: Bawd
text_entry: Exeunt Bawd, Pandar, and BOULT

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: Now, pretty one, how long have you been at this trade?

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: What trade, sir?

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: Why, I cannot name't but I shall offend.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: I cannot be offended with my trade. Please you to name it.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: How long have you been of this profession?

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: E'er since I can remember.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: Did you go to 't so young? Were you a gamester at

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: five or at seven?

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: Earlier too, sir, if now I be one.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: Why, the house you dwell in proclaims you to be a

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: creature of sale.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: Do you know this house to be a place of such resort,

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: and will come into 't? I hear say you are of

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: honourable parts, and are the governor of this place.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: Why, hath your principal made known unto you who I am?

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: Who is my principal?

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: Why, your herb-woman; she that sets seeds and roots

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: of shame and iniquity. O, you have heard something

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: of my power, and so stand aloof for more serious

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: wooing. But I protest to thee, pretty one, my

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: authority shall not see thee, or else look friendly

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: upon thee. Come, bring me to some private place:

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: come, come.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: If you were born to honour, show it now;

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: If put upon you, make the judgment good

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: That thought you worthy of it.

speaker: LYSIMACHUS
text_entry: How's this? how's this? Some more; be sage.

speaker: MARINA
text_entry: For me,
